item.title: ‘If Trump defies a Supreme Court order, will it matter to markets?’
item.description: Uncomfortable sell-side headlines for $1,000 please Alex

item.title: Putin agrees 30-day halt to strikes on Ukrainian energy infrastructure in call with Trump
item.description: Russian president sticks to tough demands for overall ceasefire and end to war

item.title: Why has Netanyahu renewed Israel’s offensive against Hamas?
item.description: Israeli premier had sought to change terms of ceasefire deal, but critics say he has a personal interest in prolonging the war

item.title: US chief justice rebukes Trump after president’s threat to impeach judges
item.description: John Roberts issues rare statement to say attacks on judicial branch of government are not ‘appropriate’

item.title: FirstFT: US chief justice issues rare rebuke to Donald Trump
item.description: Also in today’s newsletter, Putin agrees temporary halt to attacks on Ukrainian energy infrastructure, and BYD shares hit record high

item.title: Reeves to squeeze public spending further in Spring Statement
item.description: Billions of pounds of savings sought from Whitehall budgets to fill a hole in the public finances

item.title: Howard Lutnick touts Elon Musk’s Starlink for US broadband scheme
item.description: Commerce secretary urges officials to consider Trump adviser’s satellite connection for rural households

item.title: The Capital One shakedown
item.description: Business-friendly-as-a-service

item.title: Wall Street stocks slide as sell-off in tech shares picks up pace
item.description: Tesla sinks as investors shift away from riskier holdings

item.title: Netanyahu says Israel has resumed ‘fighting with force’ against Hamas
item.description: Israeli military’s renewed air strikes in Gaza kill more than 400 people, say Palestinian officials

item.title: Erdoğan’s main rival risks ban from Turkish vote after degree annulled
item.description: Popular Istanbul mayor faces potential disqualification from elections amid crackdown on opposition

item.title: How the UK’s welfare cuts will change claimants’ lives
item.description: Radical changes that will cut income for 1mn people may not get many more into work, say analysts

item.title: Tennis stars accuse governing bodies of ‘cartel’ to deny them more prize money
item.description: Players’ group behind lawsuit is affiliated with sports company backed by hedge fund tycoon Bill Ackman

item.title: Former Russian politician goes on trial in UK for breaching sanctions
item.description: The ex-governor of Sevastopol used funds for school fees and to access a Mercedes-Benz, court hears

item.title: The White House war on federal statistics
item.description: Economists and scientists worry over disappearing data and advisory groups

item.title: Sterling climbs above $1.30 for first time since November
item.description: Pound has rebounded this year amid stubbornly high UK inflation and a broad dollar retreat

item.title: Germany’s parliament approves Merz’s €1tn spending plan
item.description: Chancellor-in-waiting uses outgoing Bundestag to loosen debt brake and unleash investments in defence and infrastructure

item.title: Will anybody buy a ‘Mar-a-Lago accord’?
item.description: The US president wants both to protect domestic manufacturing and hold the dollar as the reserve currency

item.title: Brussels seeks to purchase weapons for entire EU
item.description: European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen proposes central arms reserve capitals could draw from

item.title: Europe’s moment is more than reheated Gaullism
item.description: Macron may not yet be bragging about it, but his crusade for strategic autonomy seems at long last to be vindicated

item.title: Labour unveils disability benefits cuts that aim to save over £5bn
item.description: Move risks stoking biggest backbench rebellion of Keir Starmer’s premiership

item.title: What auto bosses worry will be Trump’s next target in tariff war
item.description: Executives are concerned that levies on components could be in the president’s sights

item.title: Hong Kong’s cargo sector faces a tariff test
item.description: City’s strategic position makes it increasingly vulnerable to escalating geopolitical tensions between US and China

item.title: UK’s red tape cut should follow business world’s dotted lines
item.description: Companies undergoing efficiency drives know that such a mission calls for hard numbers and goals

item.title: Economists forecast slowing US growth and increased inflation
item.description: Also in today’s newsletter, US’s campaign against the Houthis and the man moving Meta to the right
